unnormalised: Athlete biographies offer a captivating window into the lives of individuals who have dedicated themselves to the pursuit of sporting excellence. These narratives are more than just chronicles of victories and defeats; they delve into the character, resilience, and unwavering determination that define true champions. From the dusty maidans of small-town India to the grand stadiums of the world, these stories resonate with audiences of all backgrounds.

unnormalised: Take, for instance, the biography of Milkha Singh, "The Flying Sikh." His journey from a refugee of the Partition in 1947 to an Olympian runner is a testament to the power of the human spirit. Overcoming immense personal tragedy, he became a symbol of hope for a nation finding its feet. His near miss at the 1960 Rome Olympics, finishing fourth in the 400m race, remains a poignant reminder of both his extraordinary talent and the cruel realities of competition.
